replies.author: @Mortiel
replies.text:
‚Äã@CVE42287 You kinda swap between comparing the entire state of Texas to the city of LA to the state of California. 

Both states have large amounts of land that could be used for housing, but obviously the major Texas cities have more flat land around them for development than the major cities in California.

Another factor is natural disasters: Both states have their own natural disaster issues, but wildfires in California are far more widespread than the hurricane zone in Texas (largely due to California's own choices).

Finally, economic opportunity isn't zero sum: Both California and Texas have booming economies with growth in various sectors. A couple prominent California companies did publicly leave California for Texas or Florida, but I don't think that had a measurable impact to either states' GDP. The difference is that the median income vs cost of living in major economic sectors of California (LA, SF) vs Texas (Austin, DFW) is dramatically different... The median income is like 5-10% lower in Texas while the cost of living is on average 15-20% lower. In other words, you make _slightly_ less in Texas, but everything costs _dramatically_ less.

replies.author: @98Bagel98
replies.text: I worked in sanitary sewer for a my local government for a little while. Right of way work is expensive, since there are lots of requirements. Typically, the party building has to pay for Right of way permits, pay fees to the public for the closing of any public infrastructure like streets, sidewalks ect. Anytime asphalt or concrete is involved its expensive, in my experience. You need all the equipment, plumbers, an excavation crew, a paving crew, flagging crew, and if there's a sidewalk, you will need concrete finishers. It gets really expensive and fast. My larger question is why didnt gram look into using a sewer packer to make the repair? Where i worked, we would try and use packers when wver possible as if it can be used will save a ton of money and resources. Maybe LA doesnt allow those kinds of repairs which could save millions of dollars.

author: @TimeOfTroubles73
text: About 10 years ago my Father and I were thinking about partnering on an apartment building in the inland empire, California.  The place we were looking at was abandoned and completely dilapidated. In our naivety we thought we‚Äôd get the place at a decent price which would leave us plenty of money for renovations. We started looking into who owned the building and how much they were looking to unload it for.  Turns out the company which owned it left it that way on purpose and used it to report it at a loss for tax write-off purposes.  So the tax codes are so ass-backward that it was more financially advantageous for the company which owned the building to keep it empty and in ruinous condition than it would have been to invest money into it and collect rent from tenants.  Only in California.

author: @fahs
text:
I live in NorCal.   Built a ADU on my farm in a rural area for   The entire project cost me 42K for the structure.  Then there are the other costs.....

The permits ran me 8K.
They failed me on 13 violations, 11 of which did not exist.  I fixed the TWO things, had them come back out, and POOF!  Those eleven suddenly passed.
The inspector smoked while in the house.
The inspector broke my sprinklers and refused to fix them.  The only reason I got them to admit it was when I let them know I had them on camera.  Broke the sprinkler head, and in doing so jacked up the control box.  I fixed it myself for 100 bucks, but it took me three hours to fix.
The inspector looked at the main house and filed a complaint that I had an illegal septic.  (I didnt) Took me three months to get it straightened out.  Apparently, the burden of proof was on me.
After the final inspection, received a letter telling me that my property taxes were going up 9K a year because of the added value to my property, and that I owed them 27K in back property taxes because the value of the house had gone up SINCE THE TIME OF PURCHASE TEN YEARS PRIOR.

A 42K project ended up costing me an additional 44K in administrative costs.  People that did absolutely NOTHING on my project were my greatest cost.  Well, I guess the county employees need to get their bonuses from somewhere.  

All the while, homeless people are smoking meth a mile away from my house and pooping on the street.  The county could care less about that.

author: @iOSAT
text:
When I was living in California my neighbor built an ADU in their backyard for his daughter (and her child) after leaving her abusive husband.

He had his detached garage behind his house torn down in order to build an entirely new structure. He‚Äôd been parking in that garage for the past 20 years I lived next to him. Along the way he followed every code, permit, and law to the letter.

The last inspector came to issue the CoA‚Ä¶ and told them the driveway access to the ADU was too narrow and therefore the structure could not legally be occupied. There was no way to widen the driveway (which he has been using for the ~30 years he owned the home) short of removing about 6‚Äù of his house.

It took them over a year to get the CoA and it was ONLY because the parking and vehicle access laws around ADUs changed.

replies.author: @iOSAT
replies.text:
@B@BlasphemousBuddha420 another one for you then: a buddy of mine owns a high end car storage facility in socal. They had the plans approved, ready and good to go following city code and permitting requirements along the way. Spaces at this place go for upwards of $1200/mo, lots of multi-million dollar cars.

Initial fire inspector comes in for a walk through and says they can‚Äôt have the lifts in the originally permitted layout for firefighter access reasons, so they have to pay for new plans and permits, and ultimately remove 4 lifts that have 4 cars each, that‚Äôs about $20k/mo in potential revenue.

Building gets finished and at the final walkthrough with actual fire chief for the city he looks around, and says, ‚Äúhuh, any reason you configured them this way?‚Äù

When he explained it was the fire inspector that told him he had to the chief say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not allowing my guys up there if there‚Äôs a fire, that‚Äôs why you have sprinklers!‚Äù
